Award.AwardTitle: International Symposium on Equatorial Aeronomy (ISEA); October 19-23, 2015; Bahir Dar, Ethiopia
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will provide partial support for the International Symposium on Equatorial Aeronomy (ISEA) which will provide opportunities for the establishment of new international scientific collaborations and for facilitating coordinated long term data collection in the African sector. The travel support will provide opportunities for young scientists and graduate students from the US to interact with established and emerging scientists on the international stage.
The ISEA conference is held approximately every three to four years and brings together international researchers to advance the understanding of the ionosphere-thermosphere-magnetosphere (ITM) coupling which impacts space weather, navigation, and communication systems. The location at Bahir Dar, Ethiopia, will facilitate future efforts in data collection in the African sector by engaging local scientists. This will address the longitudinal and hemispheric dependence of equatorial ionospheric effects and space weather.
This award will be jointly funded by the NSF Aeronomy Program and the Office of International Science and Engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The International Symposium on Equatorial Aeronomy (ISEA) is held approximately every three to four years, and is a major gathering of scientists around the world interested in studying the low-latitude atmosphere and ionosphere, as well as coupling with higher latitudinal regions. Each ISEA represents an opportunity for researchers to share their most recent results as well as discuss possibilities for future campaigns and experiments. 

During the last few years, a significant number of small-to-medium scale instruments have been either deployed or in the process of deployment in Africa. In addition to new scientific discoveries and advancing space science research in Africa by establishing scientific collaborations between scientists in developed and developing nations, the deployment of those instruments spontaneously increases the number of African space scientists as well as boosts the importance of space science awareness in many African countries.

In order to develop space science research infrastructure within Africa, space science educational infrastructure also needs to be developed to support the long-term operation and use of the science instrumentation. One way to address this concern is to increase and facilitate a continuous strong interaction between scientists from developed countries and African young professors and postgraduate students.

In order to foster human interactions and to further geospace research in the African sector, the 14th ISEA conference was held successfully in Bahir Dar, Ethiopia during 19-23 October 2015 with partial support from this NSF grant. The conference was well attended by in excess of 125 participants from 27 nations. Of these delegates, about 45% came from more than 10 different African countries, about 25% were from the USA, and the remaining 30% were from other countries that include Europe, Asia, and South America.

Compelling oral and poster papers, for each scientific theme, were presented at the conference. For all five science sessions as well as for a session on "Future opportunities using upcoming new mission and planned ground-based instrumentation", there were approximately 76 oral presentations, with the main focus remaining on observation and modeling efforts toward understanding the unique space weather events occurring in the African region.

In summary, the 14th ISEA conference was successful in all aspects. In addition to its function as a venue for scientific discussion, the meeting served as an effective vehicle and brought African Space Scientists together in a forum in which they could meet and make contacts with international colleagues in the field. A number of follow-on collaborations have been established as a result of such similar conferences and workshops. More importantly, a large number of students were exposed to the Space Science field and had a unique opportunity to have a one-on-one discussion with successful scientists in the field. The results emphasize the importance of meetings like the 14th ISEA conference as a crucial part of scientific research not only for Africans, but also for scientists from other emerging and well established national science programs.
